swallowed, and absorbed by marine organisms

Small fish eat plankton and sea
whales absorb toxins from the water, and
increase as larger fish species consume
The next generation of indicators for mercury will require improved
monitoring globally. Metrics to link emissions to health impacts are also
Mercury is a chemical element used in products such as button cell
batteries and fluorescent bulbs. Monitoring is inconsistent and
improved indicators are needed to better connect emissions to health.
globally, and there are major gaps.
WHAT CAN WE DO ABOUT IT?
Mercury poses a range of human

text.tspan: There are no consistent indicators to describe
human risk exposure to mercury through
occupational tasks. A gap exists between
what is measured at the source and the
Ingesting toxic metals can have serious effects on the kidney, liver, central
consume is absorbed by your intestinal tract and enters the blood stream.
Gaseous mercury is also efficiently absorbed when inhaled.
Pirrone, Nicola, Wenche Aas, Sergio Cinnirella, Ralf Ebinghaus, Ian M. Hedgecock, Jozef Pacyna, Francesca Sprovieri, and Elsie
M. Sunderland. "Toward the next generation of air quality monitoring: Mercury." Atmospheric Environment 80 (2013): 599-611.

g.text: For more information: see Pirrone et al. (2013). Toward the Next Generation of Air Quality Monitoring: Mercury. Atmospheric Environment 80:599-611.

text.tspan: permanent global monitoring network to ensure that
atmospheric Hg concentration trends is needed.
HEALTH. There are no indicators that link together Hg
emissions with health impacts via seafood consumption.
Commercial marine fish account for >90% of mercury
exposure in the U.S., mainly from pelagic marine fish
Especially south of 40–60°N, is relatively unexplored
territory with respect to Hg. The next generation
monitoring absolutely must address this gap, especially
if global patterns of Hg are to be understood.
methods require high investment and running costs.
The development of simpler and less expensive
methods is needed. Investment in developing new low
cost sensors and an expansion in the number of
permanent Hg monitoring sites worldwide is needed.
At monitoring sites, mercury is measured in air, while at some mercury is also measured
in precipitation. Globally, there are still major gaps in monitoring, particularly in the
unexplored territory with respect to Hg.
Monitoring at these sites is useful for
transport patterns, and how these are
102 countries and 1 party have signed on to the Minimata Convention - the
first treaty to protect human health and the environment from mercury.
Mercury is a global treaty to protect human
health and the environment from the
adverse effects of mercury. It was agreed
signed the Convention. It includes a
ban on new mercury mines, the phase-out
of existing ones, control measures on
regulation of the informal sector for
now been performed on a sampling campaign
basis in a number of parts of the world,
and in some areas repeatedly. Exceptions
most oceans, where data are still patchy.
Mercury in the rainwater settles in lakes and rivers, where
microorganisms convert it to a highly toxic form called
methylmercury, which is then absorbed by algae.
Methylmercury (MeHg) is the most toxic form
of mercury that accumulates in the aquatic
food web. It can cause a variety of negative
health effects, such as long-term IQ
from the ocean. Only about 1/3 of
the Hg emitted to the atmosphere
is derived from point and other
Most of the Hg emitted from
deposition, and natural re-emission of mercury
result in only coarse spatial and temporal
